Message.Title: INTC is one of 5 Dow stocks leading the way
Message.Msg: in short interest. No surprise here. Down week coming. Warning coming soon.

Message.Title: A much better outlook of Intel's future than what Piper Jaffray says.
Message.Msg: This comes from a Motley Fool article. "I fully understand why short-sellers are skeptical of Intel, but I don't believe they're seeing the big picture. Intel's decline in PC's will be slow and gradual, and it remains a source of consistent cash flow in the meantime. In addition, Intel is in line to be the prime beneficiary of the big data center evolution, with its next-generation processing chips being used by big name storage companies. Intel has also begun to edge its way into the tablet microprocessing market with a lion's share of the Windows OS tablets and just last week with the announcement that its microprocessors were found in the Samsung Galaxy Note 3." I will add some details to that. Intel's data center group is poised to show growth in the neighborhood of 10% to 20% annually. It would have to be much closer to the 20% amount if smartphone and tablet growth expectations come to be true. The more features that get added to mobile products the more necessary it will be to add to the server base. As for the PC group. Intel has given us some data points in previuos investor meetings where they have seen affordability rates increase in emergin markets for PC products. And as these new customers come into the PC world, they will most likely choose a full computing product such as desktops and laptops rather than limited function entertainment products such as tablets. They will certainly go for the best bang for the buck. So at any time, Intel could actually see nice growth numbers in their PC group revenues. And the design wins such as the Samsung Galaxy 3 will be a whole new revenue stream for Intel. The tablet wins that Intel gets will not cannibalize their own laptop and desktop revenues. They will most likely cannibalize the iPads and other tablets that decide not to use the cutting edge processors from Intel.

Message.Title: Beware the Senile Shills
Message.Msg: They are easy to spot: 1.) They repeat themselves endlessly, saying the same thing over and over and over again - hoping to occasionally be right. But they've been wrong since November and given Intel's roadmap, technology and manufacturing, there is no reason to doubt that they will continue their losing streak. 2.) They love the content-free post: Their opinion (always the sky is falling or is going to fall) without any support, logic, facts or analysis. It appears to be all that they are capable of. 3.) They never document their positions but this doesn't stop them from finding fault with those who might. If the market clearly demonstrates them to be wrong (like for the last six months), then they either go silent or cherry pick the past to find a comparison that covers their trail. 4.) They have failed to note in advance almost every significant market move but are masters of "I told you so" after the fact. But mostly they just repeat themselves endlessly. Things like "warning coming". We've heard this almost every day for the last six months while the stock has moved up by over 5 bucks. Just say no to the senile shill set. They prolly don't remember what they had for breakfast...

Message.Msg: http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424127887323844804578527402553137058.html?mod=WSJ_hpp_sections_personalfinance Piper Jaffray's downgrade presents a good buy opportunity to buy....

Topic.Title: Intel's Share Price Could Double

Message.Msg: Analysts are rated based on stock price performance since the last upgrade/downgrade. Since the *sharp* run-up in INTC in the past 6 months (perhaps a little running ahead of its earning), perhaps it's a good time to downgrade INTC. Instead, analysts should be judged based on earning growth since the last rating change. That way their ratings will be less speculative, less volatile, and more reflective of the reality of the operations of the companies (instead of reflective of the sentiments of the market).

Topic.Title: Intel's Share Price Could Double

Endless shrinking, re-spinning, repackaging and hanging a lot of baggage off their 40 year old architecture ain't it.

Topic.Title: Can Apple build an iPad running full versions of OS 10.9 or 11?

Message.Msg: Steve Jobs left the company on auto pilot and Tim Cook has been terrified to really take command of the company. I am not holding out much hope for anything substantial. If the era of innovation is truly over for Apple the one thing that the can do is grow the depth of their product lines. An iPad Pro with Intel processor makes sense. Yet, they've watched Microsoft do a face plant with Windows 8 and know that their client base won't accept anything but one smooth, well thought out experience. To move OS/X to this level is no small task. I hope it happens soon but knowing how risk adverse Apple has become I'm not holding my breath.

Topic.Title: RULE OF THUMB FOR PAST 15 YEARS

Message.Msg: RULE OF LAW FOR ALL FINANCIAL FORECASTS Past performance is not indicative of future results. If you do not like INTC over $20 and your rule is don't buy INTC over $20, then don't buy. If you feel that INTC will go down, then short INTC. If you like INTC over $20 and Intel meets your investment criteria, then follow your investment strategies that work for you. MY OPINION: Different people have different goals and risk tolerances. Intel PE ratio contracted from 40 to 10 in the last 15 years since 1998 Dividend increased from $0.0035 per share to $0.225, that is 1/3 cent to 22.5 cents from splits 1998 June 9th Closing price $70.19 1998 June 9th Adjusted Closing price $13.63 From Intel 1998 Annual Report which had been adjusted for the April 1999 2:1 stock split $26.3 bill in Revenue $0.865 Earnings per share in 1998 was $1.73 with 2:1 split in 2000 EPS $0.865 fully diluted PE ratio 40 :Stock was trading around $70 (1998 prices and shares) with $1.73 1998 earnings for a PE ratio of 40 $4 bil capex in 1998 with 1998 dollars 64k employees

Message.Title: 2013 Retina MacBook Pro Haswell Rumors Spark Massive Surge in Trade-Ins – New Range to Debut at WWDC
Message.Msg: Rumors of a brand-new 2013 MacBook Pro range set to launch at Apple’s upcoming WWDC seem to have had a dramatic effect on current MacBook owners. Illustrating the point quite distinctly, Gazelle has this week reported that trade-ins of existing MacBook Pro models have spiked by a colossal 171% as the days tick away ahead of WWDC 2013. Analysts, observers and the majority of consumers alike have come to expect a complete overhaul of the Retina MacBook Pro range over the coming weeks, built around Intel’s revolutionary Haswell processors. From USDailyVoice

Topic.Title: 2013 Retina MacBook Pro Haswell Rumors Spark Massive Surge in Trade-Ins – New Range to Debut at WWDC

Message.Msg: Statistics form Gazelle show that the rate of MacBook Pro trade-ins has been steadily on the up for the last three months or so, though saw a massive increase over the course of the last week. This would seem to suggest a direct response to analysts’ claims that a new Retina MacBook pro range is on the way, for which a release date will be announced during Apple’s conference. In terms of what to expect, much of the spotlight falls on the 13-inch Retina MacBook Pro which has long been the favorite of the bunch – also the model that seems to have disappeared from a number of major online retailers. Along with its bigger-brothers, the new 13-inch MacBook Pro for the 2013 model year will apparently narrow the gap between the Pro range and the MacBook Air lineup, by arriving with a slimmer, sleeker and lighter overall design than ever before. The use of Intel’s Haswell chips should also allow for significantly greater overall performance, while extending battery life by up to eight hours. There’s also talk of a non-Retina option being offered among the new range this year, which could see a lower entry-level price and even more impressive battery life. From USDailyVoice

Topic.Title: Computex was a turning point for Intel

Message.Msg: My post was chopped off. I must have gotten too close to maximum keystrokes allowed. Anywhichway, if you want to see an interesting take on Intel's Computex presentation THROUGH SCEPTICAL EYES, try reading patentlyapple's article "Intel Cranks up the Volume for Next-Gen Ultrabooks & Gives us a Solid Clue about what's next for Apples iTunes".

Topic.Title: Computex was a turning point for Intel

Message.Msg: Gartner forecasts that NFC will account for only about 2 percent of total transaction value in 2013 and 5 percent of the total transaction value in 2017. While Gartner's forecast sounds pretty gloomy on this front, I think they'll be proven wrong. Intel's new initiative with MasterCard is likely to just be the tip of the iceberg. As more credit cards come on board with Intel on this front, online shopping via NFC could be a success. [The tip off for WWDC starting tomorrow:] With Intel pushing Voice Assistance with their new Core 4 processors I have to wonder if Apple will be bringing Siri to OS X as part of their Next Wave features to counter this new feature by their competitors. Additionally, Best Buy's promo noted above displays what Apps will be working with Dragon Assistant and it's clearly in view that Apple's iTunes is listed as one of them. If true, that's a nice slip-up from Best Buy giving us a heads-up. A 2012 patent filing by Apple hinted at iTunes one day working with Siri. Perhaps now is that time for this to emerge. If iTunes will supposedly be working with Dragon Assistant this fall for new Ultrabooks, is it really that much of a stretch to think that Apple will include this in their next wave of new features for OS X on Monday or as an update this fall?

Topic.Title: Computex was a turning point for Intel

Message.Msg: Well, this sounds good for both Apple and Intel...

Topic.Title: Computex was a turning point for Intel

Message.Msg: Still more from the Apple Article: Panasonic's Hot Swappable Ultrabook Battery Skaugen's next segment rounded up a few Ultrabook's coming to market later this year with some interesting new common features and some exclusive to specific OEMs. For instance, they highlighted Panasonic's forthcoming hot swappable battery that could boost Ultrabook battery life from 13 to 26 hours. Although Apple won't offer this feature in future MacBooks, they should. Most don't care about the aesthetics at of the bottom of a notebook, so why not make it functional.

Topic.Title: Computex was a turning point for Intel

Message.Msg: And still more. Everyone should just go read the article. A lot there. One Flick to Share Content on Mobile Devices with Samsung TVs Apple has a technology called AirPlay and it works fine in conjunction with a receiver called Apple TV. At Computex, Skaugen illustrated how Intel worked with Samsung to build Wireless Display WiDi right into their next generation of smart HDTVs. Intel's old WiDi methodology worked very much like Apple's in that you needed a receiver attached to a TV in order to get the content from your mobile device to your HDTV display. Intel's next generation WiDi in conjunction with Samsung (initially) will allow the user using a next generation 2-in-1 Ultrabook to simply make a flicking gesture on the display to shoot your content over to a Samsung HDTV. Eliminating the need for a standalone receiver will make this feature a more simpler and popular one going forward. Will Apple work with TV makers to get AirPlay to do the same? I'd like to think so, but I highly doubt it being that these OEMs fear Apple moving into their space. Then again, there are a few hundred million future iPhone and iPad users that these TV companies could cater to, so you never know. For now, it was a smart evolutionary move on Intel's part that will be appreciated by many over time as more HDTV OEMs sign on to the project. Skaugen announced that LG, Toshiba on others were on track to add this technology to their televisions in the future while Samsung's will debut theirs this holiday season.

Topic.Title: Computex was a turning point for Intel

Message.Msg: And still yet more: Breakthrough: New Integrated 3D Depth Cameras Coming to Intel Computers in 2H 2014 A major announcement was made at Computex regarding next-generation cameras for computers. Wide-eyed Skaugen proudly announced it this way: "This may be something that we write about for many years to come. Very quietly, in the secret rooms at Intel, we've been investing in camera technologies. And this is what we believe will be the world's first 3D Depth camera integration. And our commitment along with multiple OEM partners is to put this into notebooks, Ultrabooks and all-in-ones by the second half of 2014." He later added that tablets would be able to implement the new camera as well. Dell and Lenovo will be the first two OEMs to bring this to market with full software bundles in 2H 2014. This could be a nice advancement for computing in the coming years so as to allow for in-air gesturing and advanced gaming. Back in March 2013 Patently Apple posted a report about Apple's 2011 patent application for an advanced 3D camera. In our report's opening summary we stated that Apple had invented a killer 3D imaging camera that would apply to both still photography and video. The new cameras in development would utilize new depth-detection sensors such as LIDAR, RADAR and Laser that will create stereo disparity maps in creating 3D imagery. There's no doubt that this could be a race as to who gets this feature to market first, so may the best team win. Challenges are healthy for the market at large and we as consumers ultimately win. Could iSight 3D be in the works? Only time will tell.

Topic.Title: Computex was a turning point for Intel

Message.Msg: Conclusion: For now, I believe that Intel has the right product to bring some zest back to the PC. I'm one of the greatest fans of this new device segment ever since I covered an Apple patent showing their initial interest in this form factor all the way back to 2008 before Intel ever started banging their 2-in-1 Ultrabook drum. And for the record, Apple has recently revisited their visions for such a 2-in-1 design. Time will tell if this new notebook-tablet hybrid is a category that Apple will be late to the party with, but for now Intel is going to ramp up their marketing machine for this new category going forward and with Windows and Android behind it, it's bound to make waves in the mobile space over the coming years whether Apple sees its value or not. [Note that all of the Intel positives are pretty surprising given that this was coming from an Apple fanboi...]

Message.Title: What We Know Now
Message.Msg: Well, we know now that they shills will never offer anything in support of their views but stupidity. A comparison to Itanium? It doesn't get any lamer than that. A suggestion that Wall Street wants to send the stock back to 20. Yeah, well they have wanted to do that for six months. They wanted to do that last week. It's going to take much more than the Keystone Kop analysts of the big Wall Street firms to beat the stock down. Intel has momentum and a terrific roadmap. The ARM investors know. And the final piece of stupidity was the "Intel is late to mobility". I'm actually surprised that they didn't go with "the PC is dead". If this last week told us anything, it's that the tipping point has been reached and the ARM era is over. Where's the proof ? The 20 percent drop in the ARM stock price in reaction to Haswell, Computex and the Samsung tablet deal. And now we have the "massive surge" and "colossal spike" in Mac trade-ins in anticipation of the Intel/Haswell upgrades being announced starting tomorrow at the Apple WWDC 2013. As the Intel shills fade to black...

Topic.Title: Analyst: Intel's smartphone chip offers significant power savings vs. ARM

Message.Msg: In fact, James Mielke, vice president of engineering at ABI, told PCWorld that his firms' tests show that as the ARM providers increased the performance of their chips, the current drain scaled up as well, reducing battery life. This would imply as ARM's licensees scale up the clock speeds of their chips to meet the increasing demands of apps and other phone software, the battery life of those phones could dip as well. -------------------------- Apple need to drop ARM ASAP imo

Topic.Title: Really sickended that it looks like they want to send it to 20 again

Message.Msg: "They" probably could send it to $20. "They" pushed it down from $29 by shorting 1 mill shares per day during last summer. With fewer shares outstanding (buy back) and a 4.5% short interest, "they" will have to probably short more than 1 mil shares per day to get it back down. There are only 2 companies that have a larger short position than Intel's current 233,212,213 shares. That is Sirus at 380,333,602 shares and Frontier Communications at 236,670,581. Intel is very close to being #2. Intel's 233m share short interest is an all time high for Intel. There are several events over the summer than could disturb the back to $20 argument. One every several weeks. Major ones that I can think of are Apple WWDC next week. Earnings July 20th Dividend announcement during first week in Aug. New Haswell SKU's sprinkled during the summer along with new products. Likely introductions next q3/q4 are Bay Trail + LTE and customer endorsement. Don't worry too much. It is much less likely than you suggest unless the market itself takes a 20% drop. Intel will likely follow the market but should be a little stronger than the market until the short interest gets back into normal range.

Topic.Title: Really sickended that it looks like they want to send it to 20 again

Message.Msg: "There are several events over the summer than could disturb the back to $20 argument. One every several weeks. Major ones that I can think of are Apple WWDC next week. Earnings July 20th Dividend announcement during first week in Aug. New Haswell SKU's sprinkled during the summer along with new products. Likely introductions next q3/q4 are Bay Trail + LTE and customer endorsement." [Yes, there are many more possibilities that could send the stock to $30 rather than back to $20 in that the Intel roadmap and product pipeline are so full. The Samsung event is just one. And let no one forget that we are just six months away from 14nm FinFET production. This in and of itself should boost the stock past $30. The integrated LTE chip is another. The list is as long as Shaq's arm...] [As far as the prior drop from $29+ to $19, Intel was in a lull at the that time due to the development curves. Intel is now well past the lull and is ramping out those conditions with amazing speed as Haswell, Clover Trail+, Bay Trail and others come to market. There is no similar lull at this time for shorts to play off of. They would need an issue and they don't have one. Meanwhile there are a lot of fabrication and manufacturing issues on the ARM side of things. Intel is getting almost all of the positive press and that's likely to continue for some time. I don't see the macro or the micro factors favoring any significant push to the downside. Only a massive market correction could save the short's cookies over the rest of 2013. That's why the shills are hoping against hope they get one...]

Topic.Title: What We Know Now

Message.Msg: Seems to me that certain Analyst have a hate relationship with intel. Already all their mantras, "X86 not efficient as ARM, PC is dead, intel is cannibalising" these arguments are ripped to shreds. Problem is that these analyst have for a long time been pumping ARM, TSMC, GF as the new growth contenders. What has thrown a huge wrench into their machine, is that intel has delivered on its promises, where none of the others are even in the ball park, yet at the plate. Future seems to be moving to a situation of "In with the OLD, out with the NEW", Good, old intel has won the power efficiency, performance, process, and bring to market race. This is bringing huge growth potential to intel with respect to volume and revenue. intel already stated guidance of high single digit growth in revenues, I doubt it will have a significant decrease in margins. Simply the people who will be buying cost effective ATOM processors wont be concerned about the extra $30 for the CPU, because power/performance/flexibility/ and availability benefits far outweigh the cost savings and development cost associated with maintaining the ARM path. Apple, should they maintain their ego and maintain their ARM SOC will be left with products dead in arrival, like WinRT.

Message.Title: Intel Signs Licensing Deal with SoftKinetic for iisu Middleware
Message.Msg: During Computex in Taipei, SoftKinetic said that it has signed an agreement with Intel to license out its iisu middleware for close-range hand and finger tracking capabilities to the nation's top chip maker. This middleware will be included in Intel's Perceptual Computing Software Development Kit (SDK) which brings "new experiences" to Intel-based Ultrabooks, notebooks, AIO desktops and tablets. "Under the new agreement, Intel-based platforms can now offer these capabilities and enable thousands of applications to be developed using the SDK," SoftKinetic said. "The depth capabilities of the SDK work with the CREATIVE Interactive Gesture Camera that has been enabled with the SDK and that uses SoftKinetic DepthSense 3D time-of-flight sensor technology." The news follows a brief tease during Intel's Computex keynote, as the company revealed the new Creative Senz3D Peripheral Camera. It allows users to use voice commands and manipulate objects on the screen with short-range gestures, and is capable of filtering out all objects in the background. This new Kinect-style 3D depth camera is expected to become available in 3Q13, and integrated into Intel-based devices in the second half of 2014. From Tom's Hardware

Message.Title: Forbes: Haswell Highlights: 6 New And Noteworthy Gaming Laptops
Message.Msg: Intel INTC -0.25%‘s 4th-generation processor is here, and laptop manufactures around the globe have been assaulting inboxes with press releases and impressive specs. MSI’s GT70 was first to launch, but the powerful combination of Haswell and NVIDIA’s new 700M series of mobile GPUs is proliferating quickly, allowing thinner and lighter machines to debut at reasonable prices. Rather than regurgitate each announcement, I waited a few days and have compiled 6 recently unveiled gaming laptops that stand out based on a few factors: price, aesthetics, and/or unique features. Lenovo IdeaPad Y410p You’d be forgiven for not associating Lenovo with gaming; I didn’t until the alluring red accents of their IdeaPad Y500 keyboard caught my attention, with a reduced pricetag to match. MAINGEAR Pulse 14 The real clincher for me has always been MAINGEAR’s paint jobs, which elevate their laptops (and desktops) to great visual heights. If you’re a fan of the Glasurit paint found on expensive supercars, you’ll be pleased to know that MAINGEAR hand-paints the same stuff on this laptop. Razer Blade On paper, the new Razer Blade is the hero device representing what’s possible with the perfect union of Haswell and NVIDIA’s new 700M series of GPUs. Yes, it’s thinner than a dime — but it’s also thinner than a MacBook Air, despite packing the hardware necessary for serious gaming. Gigabyte P35K Ultrablade Razer isn’t the only company gunning for ultrathin gaming notebooks. Gigabyte recently announced their “Ultrablade,” a machine only 5mm thicker than the new Blade at 21mm, and boasting a 15.6″ full HD display. Clevo P375SM from AVADirect Now we move into the category of insanely powerful desktop replacements with the Clevo P375SM from AVADirect. [And not a word about any heat issues...]

Message.Title: Article just posted on yahoo "HP sick of Wintel"
Message.Msg: Isn't this a false statement???? I thought the first Moonshot chips were Intel and no ARM chips are 100 percent conifrmed? On the server side, HP's power-efficient Moonshot system that boasts 89% energy savings use ARM-based chips instead of Intel silicon. The company makes it clear that this isn't just an "evolutionary" improvement -- this could be revolutionary.

Topic.Title: Really sickended that it looks like they want to send it to 20 again

Message.Msg: "The stock is down a buck fifty just like that due to analysts, and that includes a big up day for the market Friday.. Not sure why you don't think other analysts can't pile on and sink the ship. They do it all the time with every stock." [The stock is up 67 cents from two weeks ago. So all the big firm scheming did was trim some of the Haswell ramp back down. In the last three weeks ARM got trimmed by about 10 bucks. Given that it is significantly a zero sum game, who do you think won the recent stock price competition? Given that the big Wall Street firms are solid ARM backers, I'd say they took it in the shorts. You can be impressed if you want. Not me. They schemed, they manipulated - and now they are down another 67 cents. They are also now down by $5.36 since November. If they were the all-powerful force you suggest, why is this? It's not as if they haven't made several concerted attempts to take the stock down since November. They have just grossly misplayed Intel based on their significant misunderstanding of the technology and trends. Now they are out of time as Intel heads into the best part of the year with a full pipeline and robust product map. And we are only six months from the arrival of Intel's 14nm FinFET volume production and game over...]
